verb.description: Come or go back to a place or person.
examples: he returned to Canada in the fall

verb.description: Give, put, or send (something) back to a place or person.
examples: complete the application form and return it to this address
the company returned a profit of 4.3 million dollars

verb.description: (of an electorate) elect (a person or party) to office.
examples: the Democrat was returned in the third district

verb.description: Continue (a wall) in a changed direction, especially at right angles.

noun.description: An act of coming or going back to a place or activity.
examples: he celebrated his safe return from the war
product areas are being developed to produce maximum returns

noun.description: An official report or statement submitted in response to a formal demand.

examples: we campaigned for the return of Young and Elkins

noun.description: A key pressed to move the carriage of an electric typewriter back to a fixed position.
A part receding from the line of the front, for example the side of a house or of a window opening.

phrases: he leaves the house to his sister in return for her kindness
Charles relinquished his claim to Burgundy in return for an indemnity of two million gold ecus from Francis.
If you're not being paid much for the job you're doing, make sure you get something out of it in return at the time.
He says he gives a lot of himself teaching, but gets a lot in return.
Sponsors are shelling out to keep its City-to-City tour going and not even asking for anything in return.
origin: Middle English: the verb from Old French returner, from Latin re- back + tornare to turn; the noun via Anglo-Norman French.
